title: Mortgage & Real Estate Financing

sections.title: Mortgage Fundamentals
sections.content:
A mortgage is a loan specifically used to purchase real estate.

- **Mortgage**: A long-term loan secured by property.
- **LTV (Loan-to-Value)**: The ratio of the loan amount to the value of the property.
- **Down Payment**: The initial payment made when buying something on credit (usually 10-20%).
- **Equity (Home)**: The difference between the market value of your home and the amount you owe on the mortgage.
- **Foreclosure**: The legal process by which a lender takes control of a property after the borrower fails to make payments.
- **Amortization**: The process of gradually paying off a debt over time through regular payments.

sections.title: Fixed vs. Variable Rates
sections.content:
Borrowers must choose how their interest is calculated:

- **Fixed-rate Mortgage**: The interest rate remains the same for the entire term of the loan.
- **ARM (Adjustable-rate Mortgage)**: The interest rate can change periodically based on a financial index (e.g., EURIBOR).
- **Grace Period**: A period in which a debt may be paid without at late fee or interest.
- **Early Repayment Charge**: A fee charged if you pay off your mortgage before the agreed term.

sections.title: Grammar Focus: Second Conditional
sections.content:
We use the second conditional to talk about hypothetical financial situations or advice.

- If I **had** a larger down payment, I **would get** a better rate. (Si tuviera una entrada mayor, conseguiría un tipo mejor).
- If the interest rates **were** lower, more people **would buy** houses. (Si los tipos fueran más bajos, más gente compraría casas).
- What **would** you **do** if you couldn't pay your mortgage? (¿Qué harías si no pudieras pagar tu hipoteca?).

**Structure**: If + **Past Simple**, + **Would** + verb.
